ground_truth: Don's eyes turn slowly toward the door as Helen stands outside, ringing the bell. She bangs on the door, rattling the doorknob helplessly, but still there is no answer and she raps on the door again. Inside, Don sits staring at the door, holding his breath not to betray his presence, bathed in sweat, with tears of terror in his eyes. He continues staring at the door as Helen turns and runs down the stairs. Mrs. Deveridge stands in her door, peering up, and she hurries to the stairwell and calls down it. Don's eyes are still on the door, now focusing on the door chain. He realizes he's forgotten to put it up, but hopes it's not too late, and with a desperate effort, he flings himself to the floor and starts inching his way to the door. Don is almost at the door when, with his last strength, he raises himself against it, stretches out his hand to get the door chain, tries to slip it in its notch, but misses. Dave, the janitor, with a ring of labelled keys in his hand, leads Helen and Mrs. Deveridge up the stairs. Dave has opened the door and holds it open as far as he can. Don tries again, but by this time the door is open, and despite Don throwing all his weight against the door, it is no use. Helen slips into Dave's place in the doorway and stands waiting until Dave and Mrs. Deveridge start downstairs. Helen then enters and closes the door behind her. A shaft of light comes from the corridor, and Don crouches behind the door. She kneels down beside Don, and they are beside the light switch. Helen snaps it on and leads Don toward it. He stares at the smooth, unstained wall as she seats him on the bed and turns on the bed lamp. Don is panting hard, completely oblivious of the fact that Helen is in the room. On the armchair near the kitchen door lies Helen's leopard coat. Helen lies asleep on the couch, using the pillow and the comforter from Wick's bed. In the doorway to the bedroom stands Don, wearing the dark suit he wore to the opera, as his eyes shift from Helen to the coat while he is just tying his tie. Very cautiously, he begins to tiptoe toward the chair. He picks up the leopard coat and starts towards the entrance door. Just as he is slipping out, Don shuts the door behind him. Helen then flings open the door and runs out. In the next second, Helen hurries into the shot, wearing Wick's foulard dressing gown. She runs to the banister and looks down, barefooted, just wearing the foulard dressing gown.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Don's optics rotate gradually toward the portal as Helen stands outside, ringing the chime. She thumps on the portal, shaking the doorknob powerlessly, but still there is no reply and she knocks on the portal again. Inside, Don sits gazing at the portal, holding his breath not to reveal his presence, drenched in perspiration, with tears of dread in his optics. He continues gazing at the portal as Helen turns and dashes down the stairs. Mrs. Deveridge stands in her portal, peering up, and she hastens to the stairwell and calls down it. Don's optics are still on the portal, now concentrating on the portal chain. He realizes he's forgotten to put it up, but hopes it's not too late, and with a frantic attempt, he flings himself to the floor and starts inching his way to the portal. Don is almost at the portal when, with his last strength, he elevates himself against it, extends out his hand to get the portal chain, tries to slip it in its notch, but misses. Dave, the janitor, with a loop of labeled keys in his hand, guides Helen and Mrs. Deveridge up the stairs. Dave has unlocked the portal and holds it open as far as he can. Don tries again, but by this time the portal is open, and despite Don throwing all his weight against the portal, it is no use. Helen slips into Dave's place in the doorway and stands waiting until Dave and Mrs. Deveridge start downstairs. Helen then enters and shuts the portal behind her. A beam of illumination comes from the corridor, and Don crouches behind the portal. She kneels down beside Don, and they are beside the illumination switch. Helen snaps it on and leads Don toward it. He stares at the smooth, unstained barrier as she seats him on the bed and turns on the bed lamp. Don is panting hard, completely oblivious to the fact that Helen is in the room. On the armchair near the kitchen portal lies Helen's leopard coat. Helen lies asleep on the sofa, using the cushion and the comforter from Wick's bed. In the doorway to the bedroom stands Don, wearing the dark suit he wore to the opera, as his optics shift from Helen to the coat while he is just tying his tie. Very cautiously, he begins to tiptoe toward the chair. He picks up the leopard coat and starts towards the entrance portal. Just as he is slipping out, Don shuts the portal behind him. Helen then flings open the portal and dashes out. In the next second, Helen hurries into the shot, wearing Wick's foulard dressing gown. She dashes to the banister and looks down, barefooted, just wearing the foulard dressing gown.

From the corridor comes a shaft of light, and the door is crouched behind by Don. Beside Don, she kneels down, and they are led beside the light switch by Helen, who snaps it on. He is led toward it by her and stares at the smooth, unstained wall as she seats him on the bed and turns on the bed lamp. Don pants hard, completely oblivious to the fact that the room is occupied by Helen. On the armchair near the kitchen door, Helen's leopard coat lies. The couch is slept on by Helen, using the pillow and the comforter from Wick's bed. In the doorway to the bedroom, Don stands, wearing the dark suit he wore to the opera, as his eyes shift from Helen to the coat while the tie is being tied by him. Very cautiously, the chair is tiptoed toward by him. The leopard coat is picked up by him, and he starts towards the entrance door. Just as he is slipping out, the door is shut behind him by Don. She runs to the banister and looks down, barefooted, just wearing the foulard dressing gown.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Don slowly turns his eyes toward the door as Helen stands outside, ringing the bell and banging on the door. Despite her efforts, there's no answer. Inside, Don sits, breath held, sweating and terrified. He watches as Helen runs down the stairs, passing Mrs. Deveridge, who calls down the stairwell. Don realizes he forgot to secure the door chain and, desperate, crawls to the door. Just as he's about to lock it, Dave, the janitor, arrives with Helen and Mrs. Deveridge. Dave opens the door, rendering Don's efforts useless. Helen enters as Dave and Mrs. Deveridge leave. In the room, Helen switches on the light and helps Don to the bed, where he remains unaware of her presence. Helen is asleep on the couch, using Wick's beddings, while Don, in his opera suit, eyes her leopard coat. He tiptoes, takes the coat, and exits, shutting the door. Helen quickly runs out wearing Wick's foulard dressing gown, barefoot, looking down from the banister.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Don watches the door as Helen rings the bell and bangs on it without an answer. Inside, Don, terrified and sweating, stares at the door, hoping not to be discovered. Helen leaves, passing Mrs. Deveridge, who calls down the stairs. Realizing he forgot the door chain, Don crawls to secure it but fails. Dave, the janitor, lets Helen and Mrs. Deveridge in. Despite Don's attempts, the door opens, and Helen enters. She switches on the light, leading Don to the bed, where he remains unaware of her presence. Helen sleeps on the couch, and Don dresses for the opera, taking her leopard coat. As he exits, Helen tries to follow, wearing Wick's dressing gown, and looks down the stairs.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
As Don's eyes gradually turn toward the door, he notices Helen standing resolutely outside, persistently ringing the bell. She vigorously bangs on the door, the doorknob rattling loudly with each helpless attempt she makes, yet despite her efforts, there remains a deafening silence—no answer comes. Determined, she knocks on the door once more. Meanwhile, inside the room, Don sits motionless, his eyes fixed intently on the door. He scarcely breathes, holding it in with intense concentration to avoid betraying any hint of his presence. Beads of sweat cascade down his face, mingling with the tears of terror brimming in his eyes. His unwavering gaze remains locked on the door even as Helen turns abruptly and hurries down the stairs. Mrs. Deveridge stands in her doorway, observing the scene with a keen eye, and she quickly moves toward the stairwell, calling out down the dimly lit steps.

Don's eyes remain glued to the door, now zeroing in on the door chain. A sudden realization dawns upon him—he has forgotten to secure it. Filled with anxiety, he hopes fervently that it is not too late. With a desperate surge of effort, he throws himself to the floor and slowly inches his way toward the door. Just as he is about to reach it, he musters his last reserves of strength, pushing himself upright against the door. Stretching out his trembling hand, he attempts to latch the door chain into its notch, but his exhausted grip falters, and he misses. At that moment, Dave, the janitor, emerges, accompanied by Helen and Mrs. Deveridge, leading them up the stairs with a jangle of keys in hand. Dave unlocks the door and holds it open as wide as possible. Don tries once more to secure the chain, but by now, the door swings open. Despite Don’s valiant efforts to throw his weight against it, his resistance proves futile. Helen slides seamlessly into Dave's space in the doorway, standing there momentarily until Dave and Mrs. Deveridge begin their descent downstairs. Helen then steps boldly inside and closes the door behind her with a decisive click. A narrow shaft of light beams in from the corridor, illuminating the space where Don crouches behind the door. She kneels down beside him, and together they are positioned near the light switch. Helen flicks it on and gently guides Don toward the illumination. He gazes blankly at the smooth, unstained wall as she seats him gently on the bed and switches on the bedside lamp. Don breathes heavily, utterly oblivious to Helen's presence in the room, consumed by his own thoughts.

In the armchair adjacent to the kitchen door, Helen's luxurious leopard coat lies draped carelessly. Exhausted, Helen sleeps soundly on the couch, using the pillow and comforter borrowed from Wick's bed for comfort. Meanwhile, in the bedroom doorway, Don stands, wearing the dark suit he had worn the night they attended the opera. His eyes shift cautiously from Helen to the coat as he meticulously ties his tie. With the utmost caution, he begins to tiptoe toward the chair. Gently picking up the leopard coat, he starts to make his way toward the entrance door. Just as he is quietly slipping out, Don ensures the door is shut securely behind him. In a swift motion, Helen flings the door open and hurries out after him. In the very next moment, Helen returns hurriedly into the scene, now clad in Wick's foulard dressing gown. She races to the banister, her eyes scanning downward, barefoot and enveloped only in the silky foulard dressing gown.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
As Don's observant eyes gradually turn in the direction of the door, he becomes aware of Helen standing firmly outside, persistently ringing the bell in hopes of gaining entry. She is vigorously banging on the door, making the doorknob rattle loudly with each futile attempt she makes to open it, yet despite her repeated efforts, there is an overwhelming silence—no answer comes from within. Undeterred and steadfast in her resolve, she knocks on the door once more with determination. Meanwhile, inside the dimly lit room, Don sits completely motionless, his eyes fixed with intense focus on the door. He scarcely dares to breathe, holding his breath with concentrated effort to avoid betraying any sign of his presence behind the silent door. Beads of sweat continually trickle down his face, mingling with the tears of sheer terror filling his eyes. His unwavering gaze remains locked intently on the door, even as Helen abruptly turns and hurries down the stairs. Mrs. Deveridge stands in her doorway, observing the scene with a keen and watchful eye, and she quickly moves toward the stairwell, calling out down the dimly illuminated steps.

Don’s eyes stay fixated on the door, now focusing intently on the door chain. A sudden realization dawns upon him—he has forgotten to secure it. Overcome with anxiety, he fervently hopes it is not too late to rectify his oversight. With a desperate surge of energy, he throws himself to the floor and slowly inches his way toward the door. Just as he is about to reach his goal, he musters his remaining reserves of strength, pushing himself upright against the door. Stretching out his trembling hand, he attempts to latch the door chain into its designated notch, but his exhausted grip falters, and he misses his target. At that exact moment, Dave, the janitor, emerges with a jangle of keys, accompanied by Helen and Mrs. Deveridge, leading them up the stairs. Dave promptly unlocks the door and holds it wide open. Don attempts once more to secure the chain, but by now, the door swings completely open. Despite Don’s valiant efforts to throw his weight against it, his resistance proves futile. Helen smoothly slides into Dave's space in the doorway, pausing there momentarily until Dave and Mrs. Deveridge begin their descent downstairs. Helen then steps boldly inside, closing the door behind her with a decisive, resonating click. A narrow shaft of light beams in from the corridor, softly illuminating the space where Don crouches behind the door. She kneels beside him gently, positioning them near the light switch. Helen flicks it on and carefully guides Don toward the welcoming illumination. He stares blankly at the smooth, unstained wall as she seats him gently on the bed, switching on the bedside lamp. Don breathes heavily, utterly oblivious to Helen's presence in the room, entirely consumed by his own swirling thoughts.

In the armchair adjacent to the kitchen door, Helen's luxurious leopard coat lies draped carelessly, as if forgotten. Exhausted, Helen sleeps soundly on the couch, using the pillow and comforter that she borrowed from Wick's bed for added comfort. Meanwhile, in the bedroom doorway, Don stands, wearing the dark suit he had worn the memorable night they attended the opera. His eyes shift cautiously back and forth from Helen to the coat as he meticulously ties his tie with careful precision. With the utmost caution, he begins to tiptoe stealthily toward the chair. Gently and quietly picking up the leopard coat, he starts to make his way toward the entrance door. Just as he is quietly slipping out, Don ensures the door is shut securely behind him. In a swift motion, Helen flings the door open and hurries out after him. In the very next moment, Helen returns hurriedly into the scene, now clad in Wick's elegant foulard dressing gown. She races to the banister, scanning downward with keen eyes, barefoot and enveloped only in the silky foulard dressing gown.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As Don's eyes slowly shift toward the door, Helen stands outside, repeatedly pressing the bell in hopes of gaining his attention. She bangs on the door with increasing urgency, her hand desperately rattling the doorknob, yet still, no response comes, prompting her to rap on the door once more. Inside, Don remains seated, intently gazing at the door, his body tense as he holds his breath to mask his presence. He is drenched in sweat, his eyes brimming with tears of terror. His stare remains fixed on the door as Helen eventually turns and hastens down the stairs. Mrs. Deveridge, standing at her own door, peers upward to assess the commotion. She then quickly approaches the stairwell and calls down, her voice echoing. Don's eyes remain glued to the door, his focus shifting to the door chain. A sudden realization hits him—he has neglected to secure it—but he clings to hope that it's not too late. Summoning all his remaining energy, he flings himself to the floor and begins inching laboriously toward the door. He is nearly there when he musters his last reserves of strength to pull himself upright against the door. Stretching his hand toward the elusive door chain, he attempts to slide it into its notch but falters. Meanwhile, Dave the janitor, clutching a ring of labeled keys, escorts Helen and Mrs. Deveridge up the stairs. Dave, having unlocked the door, pulls it open as wide as possible. Don makes another valiant attempt, yet by this point, the door has swung open, and despite him throwing all his weight against it, his efforts are futile. Helen quickly replaces Dave in the doorway, standing watch as Dave and Mrs. Deveridge begin their descent. Once they are gone, Helen enters and quietly closes the door behind her. A shaft of light spills from the corridor into the room, and Don crouches behind the door, seeking refuge in the shadows. Helen kneels beside Don, who is still beside the light switch, and she flicks it on, gently guiding Don toward it. He fixates on the smooth, unstained wall as she guides him to sit on the bed and proceeds to illuminate the area with the bed lamp. Panting heavily, Don remains in a state of oblivion to Helen's presence in the room. Nearby, on the armchair close to the kitchen door, Helen's leopard coat rests. Helen, meanwhile, lies asleep on the couch, utilizing a pillow and the comforter borrowed from Wick's bed for comfort. In the bedroom doorway, Don stands dressed in the dark suit he wore to the opera, his eyes moving from Helen to the coat, his hands deftly tying his tie. With deliberate caution, he tiptoes toward the chair, retrieves the leopard coat, and makes his way toward the entrance door. As he quietly slips out, he closes the door behind him, hoping to remain undetected. However, Helen swiftly flings the door open and runs out after him. In the very next moment, Helen hurries into view, clad in Wick's foulard dressing gown, her feet bare. She races to the banister, looking downward with urgency, her bare feet gripping the floor, encased only in the flowing fabric of the dressing gown.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: As Helen stands outside ringing and banging on the door, Don remains silently inside, watching the door with fear and sweating, aware he forgot to secure the chain. Helen eventually runs down the stairs, and Mrs. Deveridge calls after her. Realizing the door might open, Don urgently crawls to secure it but misses his chance as Dave the janitor unlocks it. Helen takes Dave's place in the doorway as he and Mrs. Deveridge leave, then enters and closes the door. A light switch is near Don, and Helen turns it on, guiding him into the room and seating him on the bed beside a lamp. Don, panting heavily, remains unaware of Helen's presence. As she sleeps on the couch with a pillow and comforter, Don stands in the bedroom doorway wearing his opera suit, eyeing Helen's leopard coat. Quietly, he tiptoes to the chair, picks up the coat, and heads for the door. Shutting it behind him, Helen quickly follows, flinging the door open and rushing out barefoot in Wick's dressing gown. She peers over the banister, searching for Don.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Don's eyes turn slowly toward the door as Helen stands outside, ringing the bell of the old brownstone building known for its creaky wooden stairs. She bangs on the door, rattling the doorknob helplessly, but still there is no answer and she raps on the door again. Inside, Don sits staring at the door, holding his breath not to betray his presence, bathed in sweat from the oppressive summer heat, with tears of terror in his eyes. He continues staring at the door as Helen, a figure determined to confront the situation, turns and runs down the stairs. Mrs. Deveridge, the long-time resident known among neighbors for her curiosity, stands in her door, peering up, and she hurries to the stairwell and calls down it. Don's eyes are still on the door, now focusing on the door chain, a flimsy security measure in this aging building. He realizes he's forgotten to put it up, but hopes it's not too late, and with a desperate effort, he flings himself to the floor and starts inching his way to the door. Don is almost at the door when, with his last strength, he raises himself against it, stretches out his hand to get the door chain, tries to slip it in its notch, but misses. Dave, the janitor, a familiar face who knows every creak and groan of the building, with a ring of labelled keys in his hand, leads Helen and Mrs. Deveridge up the stairs. Dave has opened the door, using the skeleton key reserved for emergencies, and holds it open as far as he can. Don tries again, but by this time the door is open, and despite Don throwing all his weight against the door, it is no use. Helen slips into Dave's place in the doorway and stands waiting until Dave and Mrs. Deveridge start downstairs. Helen then enters and closes the door behind her. A shaft of light comes from the corridor, illuminated by the flickering bulb that was due for replacement, and Don crouches behind the door. She kneels down beside Don, and they are beside the light switch, known to be a bit temperamental at times. Helen snaps it on, and the light flickers to life as she leads Don toward it. He stares at the smooth, unstained wall, part of recent renovations aimed at modernizing the old apartment, as she seats him on the bed and turns on the bed lamp. Don is panting hard, completely oblivious of the fact that Helen, who had been struggling with insomnia since moving into the building, is in the room. On the armchair near the kitchen door lies Helen's leopard coat, a gift from her last birthday, symbolic of her bold personality. Helen lies asleep on the couch, using the pillow and the comforter from Wick's bed, remnants of a previous guest's stay. In the doorway to the bedroom stands Don, wearing the dark suit he wore to the opera, an unexpected outing that had been a rare gesture from him, as his eyes shift from Helen to the coat while he is just tying his tie. Very cautiously, he begins to tiptoe toward the chair. He picks up the leopard coat, which he knew she cherished, and starts towards the entrance door. Just as he is slipping out, Don shuts the door behind him in an attempt to leave quietly. Helen then flings open the door and runs out, determined to catch up. In the next second, Helen hurries into the shot, wearing Wick's foulard dressing gown, an unusual choice for her that suggests urgency. She runs to the banister and looks down, barefooted, just wearing the foulard dressing gown, determined to find answers.

In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. A shaft of light comes from the corridor and Don crouches behind the door. She kneels down beside Don and they are beside the light switch. Helen snaps it on and leads Don toward it. He stares at the smooth unstained wall as she seats him on the bed and turns on the bed lamp. Don is panting hard completely oblivious of the fact that Helen is in the room. On the armchair near the kitchen door lies Helen's leopard coat. Helen lies asleep on the couch using the pillow and the comforter from Wick's bed. In the doorway to the bedroom stands Don wearing the dark suit he wore to the opera as his eyes shift from Helen to the coat while he is just tying his tie. Very cautiously he begins to tiptoe toward the chair. He picks up the leopard coat and starts towards the entrance door. Just as he is slipping out Don shuts the door behind him. Helen then flings open the door and runs out. In the next second Helen hurries into the shot wearing Wick's foulard dressing gown. She runs to the banister and looks down barefooted just wearing the foulard dressing gown.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Don's eyes turn slowly toward the door as Helen stands outside ringing the bell. She bangs on the door rattling the doorknob helplessly but still there is no answer and she raps on the door again. Inside Don sits staring at the door holding his breath not to betray his presence bathed in sweat with tears of terror in his eyes. He continues staring at the door as Helen turns and runs down the stairs. Mrs Deveridge stands in her door peering up and she hurries to the stairwell and calls down it. Don's eyes are still on the door now focusing on the door chain. He realizes he is forgotten to put it up but hopes it is not too late and with a desperate effort he flings himself to the floor and starts inching his way to the door. In the doorway to the bedroom stands Don wearing the dark suit he wore to the opera as his eyes shift from Helen to the coat while he is just tying his tie. Very cautiously he begins to tiptoe toward the chair. He picks up the leopard coat and starts towards the entrance door. Just as he is slipping out Don shuts the door behind him. Helen then flings open the door and runs out. In the next second Helen hurries into the shot wearing Wick's foulard dressing gown. She runs to the banister and looks down barefooted just wearing the foulard dressing gown.

Inside Don sits staring at the door holding his breath not to betray his presence bathed in sweat with tears of terror in his eyes. Helen then flings open the door and runs out. In the next second Helen hurries into the shot wearing Wick's foulard dressing gown. She runs to the banister and looks down barefooted just wearing the foulard dressing gown.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Gina's ears pivot quickly toward the window as Norman floats inside, strumming the harp. He taps on the window, shaking the curtain mournfully, but still, there is no response, and he taps on the window once more. Outside, Gina kneels glancing at the window, biting her lip not to reveal her thoughts, coated in dust, with grains of surprise in her ears. She continues glancing at the window as Norman turns and leaps across the rooftops. Mr. Jennings swims in his pond, gazing down, and he trundles to the dock and whispers across it. Gina's ears are still on the window, now gazing at the curtain tassel. She realizes she's forgotten to adjust it, but hopes it's not too late, and with a frantic twist, she rolls herself to the closet and begins shuffling her way to the window. Gina is nearly at the window when, with her last breath, she raises herself against it, stretches out her toe to grab the curtain tassel, attempts to hook it on its peg, but misses. Carla, the gardener, with a stack of numbered cards in her basket, guides Norman and Mr. Jennings across the rooftops. Carla has lifted the window and holds it ajar as wide as she can. Gina attempts again, but by now the window is wide, and despite Gina tossing all her patience at the window, it is to no avail. Norman leaps into Carla's spot on the rooftop and stands watching until Carla and Mr. Jennings soar skyward. Norman then slides in and closes the window softly. A thread of mist comes from the garden, and Gina lies beneath the window. He slumps down beside Gina, and they are beside the light socket. Norman flips it off and pushes Gina away from it. She gazes at the rough, unmarked sky as he perches her on the bench and switches on the desk fan. Gina is whispering softly, utterly unaware of the fact that Norman is nearby. On the footstool next to the hallway window sits Norman's kangaroo hat. Norman sits upright on the bench, holding the cushion and the teddy bear from Carla's shelf. In the roof garden under the stars dances Gina, wearing the plaid jacket she wore to the concert, as her ears shift from Norman to the hat while she is just brushing her ear. Very confidently, she begins to stomp toward the footstool. She lifts the kangaroo hat and shuffles towards the tunnel entrance. Just as she is sneaking through, Gina seals the window behind her. Norman then throws open the window and slides out. In the blink of an eye, Norman glides into the frame, clutching Carla's silk ribbon scarf. He flits to the staircase and peers up, barefooted, wearing only the silk ribbon scarf.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Don anxiously watches the door as Helen frantically knocks and rings the bell outside. Inside, Don struggles with fear, hoping Helen will leave without realizing he's there. As Helen departs, Don crawls to secure the door chain but is interrupted when Dave, the janitor, unlocks the door for Helen and Mrs. Deveridge. Helen enters and comforts Don, who is still tense and unaware of her presence. Later, Helen sleeps on the couch with Don's leopard coat nearby. Dressed in a dark suit, Don cautiously takes the coat and quietly exits. Helen wakes, runs out after him, and looks down the stairs, barefoot in a dressing gown.
